messages.text: Provide GEOJSON datasets of carbon emissions in North America between 2010 and 2020

You are looking for GEOJSON datasets of carbon emissions in North America, specifically covering the period between 2010 and 2020. Based on the search results, several datasets seem relevant to your query, although some may require further specification or processing to exactly match your requirements.

1. **State carbon dioxide emissions data**: This dataset from the U.S. Energy Information Administration provides annual state-level estimates of energy consumption, prices, and expenditures for jet fuel, which can be related to carbon emissions. It's available at [https://www.eia.gov/environment/emissions/state/](https://www.eia.gov/environment/emissions/state/). While not directly in GEOJSON format, the data could potentially be converted or used in conjunction with geographic information systems (GIS) to match your spatial needs.

2. **Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions for Indianapolis, Indiana**, and **Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions for Baltimore, Maryland**: These datasets are part of the Hestia Project, which quantifies and visualizes greenhouse gas emissions in urban areas. Although focused on specific cities, they provide high-resolution data (at the county level with 200m grid resolution) from 2010 to 2015. These can be found at [https://doi.org/10.18434/T4/1503341](https://doi.org/10.18434/T4/1503341) and [https://doi.org/10.18434/T4/1503342](https://doi.org/10.18434/T4/1503342), respectively. The data is detailed but might need aggregation or combination with other datasets for a comprehensive North America view.

3. **Anthropogenic Carbon Emission System, 2012-2017, Version 2**: Provided by NASA, this dataset estimates hourly carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion at a 1-km resolution for the coterminous United States. It covers the years 2012 through 2017 and is divided into ten distinct emissions source sectors. The data is available in NetCDF format at [https://search.earthdata.nasa.gov/search?q=NACP_ACES_V2_1943&ac=true](https://search.earthdata.nasa.gov/search?q=NACP_ACES_V2_1943&ac=true). While not directly in GEOJSON, the high spatial resolution could be utilized in a GIS for conversion or analysis.

4. **Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions Inventory for Urban Regions**: This dataset provides data products for several U.S. cities, including Los Angeles, Indianapolis, and the Northeast corridor, quantifying greenhouse gases emitted by urban regions. Available from 2010, these datasets offer high spatial and temporal resolution CO2 concentrations. The data can be accessed at [https://doi.org/10.18434/t4/1502503](https://doi.org/10.18434/t4/1502503).

To better assist you, it would be helpful to know if you have a specific country or region within North America you're interested in, or if there are particular sectors or types of carbon emissions you'd like to focus on. Additionally, the level of detail or granularity for the GEOJSON data (e.g., country, state, city) could help narrow down the search.

files.description: Annual state-level estimates of energy consumption, prices, and expenditures for jet fuel.
files.title: State carbon dioxide emissions data

files.description: Hestia Project quantifies, simulates and visualizes greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide emitted in urban regions.  Indianapolis data is provided at the county level (200 m grid resolution), and at hourly and yearly time frames.  It builds upon work conducted at the national scale by the Vulcan Project. These high spatial and temporal resolution datasets are available from 2010 to 2015.
files.title: Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions for Indianapolis, Indiana

files.description: Hestia Project quantifies, simulates and visualizes greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide emitted in urban regions.  Indianapolis data is provided at the county level (200 m grid resolution), and at hourly and yearly time frames.  It builds upon work conducted at the national scale by the Vulcan Project. These high spatial and temporal resolution datasets are available from 2010 to 2015.

files.description: VCPy was developed to predict evaporative emissions of VOCs from volatile chemical products. The data contains python code and inputs for VCPy v1.0 as well as an excel file containing values from the main text figures in the work of Seltzer et al. (Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, 2021).
files.title: Reactive Organic Carbon Emissions from Volatile Chemical Products

files.description: This dataset provides estimates of hourly carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from the combustion of fossil fuels at 1-km resolution for the coterminous United States (CONUS) covering the years 2012 through 2017. Emissions from the ACES model are reported for ten distinct emissions source sectors: Airports and Aircraft, Commercial Buildings, Electric Power Generation facilities, Industrial point and non-point sources, Commercial Marine Vessels, Nonroad vehicles and equipment, Oil and Gas wells and facilities, Onroad vehicles, Railway engines and yards, and Residential buildings. All emissions are reported hourly on a 1-km x 1-km spatial grid. The data are provided in NetCDF version 4 format.
files.title: Anthropogenic Carbon Emission System, 2012-2017, Version 2

files.description: This dataset provides carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide flux from fires constrained by satellite observations.The NASA Carbon Monitoring System (CMS) is designed to make significant contributions in characterizing, quantifying, understanding, and predicting the evolution of global carbon sources and sinks through improved monitoring of carbon stocks and fluxes. The System will use the full range of NASA satellite observations and modeling/analysis capabilities to establish the accuracy, quantitative uncertainties, and utility of products for supporting national and international policy, regulatory, and management activities. CMS will maintain a global emphasis while providing finer scale regional information, utilizing space-based and surface-based data and will rapidly initiate generation and distribution of products both for user evaluation and to inform near-term policy development and planning.
files.title: Global Fire carbon emissions from CMS-Flux inversions assimilating atmospheric carbon monoxide observations

files.description: Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions Inventory for Urban Regions (Hestia FFCO2) provides data products for Los Angeles Basin, Northeast corridor, Indianapolis, and other U.S. Cities. Hestia FFCO2 datasets quantify greenhouse gases (GHG), such as carbon dioxide, emitted by urban regions, since cities are major contributors of anthropogenic GHG emissions. The Hestia FFCO2 datasets provide high spatial and temporal resolution CO2 concentrations at sub-county resolutions and annual/hourly time scales, specific to the region. This data product builds upon the Vulcan Project, which grids U.S. national emissions.  Hestia FFCO2 datasets are currently available from 2010 for Los Angeles, Indianapolis, Salt Lake City, the city of Baltimore, and the Baltimore/Washington Region (Northeast Corridor).
files.title: Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions Inventory for Urban Regions

files.description: Hestia Fossil Fuel Carbon Dioxide Emissions Inventory for Urban Regions (Hestia FFCO2) provides data products for Los Angeles Basin, Northeast corridor, Indianapolis, and other U.S. Cities. Hestia FFCO2 datasets quantify greenhouse gases (GHG), such as carbon dioxide, emitted by urban regions, since cities are major contributors of anthropogenic GHG emissions. The Hestia FFCO2 datasets provide high spatial and temporal resolution CO2 concentrations at sub-county resolutions and annual/hourly time scales, specific to the region. This data product builds upon the Vulcan Project, which grids U.S. national emissions.  Hestia FFCO2 datasets are currently available from 2010 for Los Angeles, Indianapolis, Salt Lake City, the city of Baltimore, and the Baltimore/Washington Region (Northeast Corridor).
